title: House Passes Bill Decriminalizing Marijuana at Federal Level
sub_head: Measure, which would leave cannabis laws to the states, isn’t expected to be taken up by Senate
body:
WASHINGTON—The House voted to decriminalize marijuana at the federal level, the first legislation of its kind to get a vote in the chamber, though it isn’t expected to move forward and become law.
The bill, which passed 228-164, would remove cannabis from the Controlled Substances Act, leaving it to states to determine its legality. The legislation would also expunge some criminal records and impose a 5% federal tax on cannabis products to help fund programs in communities hurt by the war on drugs.
The vote was largely along party lines. Libertarian Rep. Justin Amash of Michigan and five Republicans voted in favor of the bill, including Rep. Matt Gaetz (R., Fla.) who was a cosponsor. Six Democrats voted against the bill, all centrist lawmakers.
The bill was a Democratic priority in the House, where lawmakers see it as a civil rights issue. It is not expected to move forward in the GOP-controlled Senate.
Democrats and civil-rights groups said the legislation was necessary to help end decades of arrests and incarcerations, particularly of minorities, over drug offenses.
